The envelope lay on his desk like an unwanted guest, its gold-embossed lettering gleaming mockingly under the dim lamp. He picked it up, fingers tracing the familiar seal of the publishing house that had once been his home, now a bitter reminder of his exile.

His temples throbbed as he read the invitation, each word clawing at his chest like an accusation. "Betrayer," he whispered to himself, the old label burning on his tongue like poison. He saw them too, in his mind's eye: the smug faces of those who had turned against him, their voices echoing with the same condemnation.

He felt it again, that familiar wave of shame and anger, the heavy weight of his global label pressing down upon him. "Failed journalist," he muttered, his voice barely audible in the silent room. He was no longer the renowned scribe who had once commanded respect, but a relic, an outdated model of integrity in a world that valued spin over truth.

The gala invitation seemed less like an olive branch and more like a taunt, a reminder of all he had lost. It mocked his solitude, his quiet life of principle amidst a world that had moved on without him. He was not just a retired journalist; he was a discarded one, his name now synonymous with controversy rather than credibility.

He tossed the invitation aside, its corners crinkling like the edges of his once-pristine reputation. He would not go, could not face them again, those who had cast him out and reduced him to this: a man defined by his fall from grace, labeled by their collective disdain.
